bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, July 1, 1920

div1.p: Carter describes a trip down the Guayaquil River.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, July 1, 1920
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
July 1/20
My Dear Daughter:
div1.p:
(1) I am writing with my old stylet.
Dr G I dropped from my pocket at Dr. Grille
front door - saturday night. His boy-adop-
ted - Pete found it & finding my card
in the crack of the door - made the Sherlock-
Holmes deduction that it was mine & as
Grubbs took the Manabi for Buenaventura &
Guayaquil - as the same time I shipped a-
board this vessel - the Ucayali - & as Pete
came down with him - I have it.

2) We are entering the “embosca” of the
Guayaquil River - i.e. the gulf into which
the river widens out &, it being 6.55, should
raise Puna by 8.30 or 9 & reach Guaya-
quil
2
Guayaquil by 11.30 or12 or 12.30. I presume
we leave tomorrow morning- It may
be go down the river tonight, & cross the
bar tomorrow morning- The bay is not
attempted at night. From the mouth of
the river to Payta is about 24 hours - i.e.
I get there on the 3d- As I left Balt. the mor-
ning of the 11 - or rather the train did - that
will be 22 days en route & hours! I
came down in 1415 days before- Well I
lost no time- Had been there on the 26. if
we had not stopped at Havana -- i.e, had to-
kena Pan. R. R. boat, I do not regret stay
ing over & correcting Major Bryam's proof.
Although I would not have done so of
my own volition. I had not fore know how im-
portant it was.

It has not been an agreeable trip - (a) my state
room is far toward & the pitch of the boat
is
3
is a nuisance. The vessel is crowded - & as I trans-
ferred to it on Saturday - she sailed Monday-
naturally the early passengers had prefer-
ence- Also I transferred in Panama & the
rooms were given out in Colon - hence I
got “picked a lemon” as Henry would say. How-
ever I have a room to myself. & many have not.
There are two French Aviators aboard for Lima
to instruct the Peruvian Army - one at my
table to whom I translate & advise on the
menu. A nice fellow, 1st Lieut. Also a
naturalist going to the high land in the
Southern Equador - where it seems there is
American Company & gold mines. He is a very
interesting man: Knows Bringham of Yale, &
has worked in these countries for 22 years: The
Chief Engineer- aGreenock man - was Asst.
Engineer on the Am. Dredge on the old
Panama
4
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Panama Canal. Thinks he saved his life
by winning $9,000 - at Rou-
lette - at the
Club Inter-
national - in Panama; with which he left
the Isthmus & went to N.O,. He too is inter-
esting- As is an American Engeer.- Mott
Mott - who worked in Mexico for 16 years & then
went to France (has Captain on his Card but enlisted
as a private he says). He goes down to representing
the Curtis people to see if he can establish Avi-
ation on a Commercial basis - especially for
the Post. Office. He has three planes with him. I
tell him - that there is doubtless an opening in
Peru but a much greater field in Colum-
bia - 9 days on a weekly mail - from Bogota
to Baranguilla - & a good one in Equador-
Columbia has an abundance of money-gold I
am told - from the high price of Coffee & hides & - to some
extent - Cattle. There are - so Gen. Harding says - about
40.000
5
40.000 cattle on the zone pastures - mainly from
Columbia. I judge.

Did I tell you that Irazu had had many
irruptions of smoke & cinders the last two
years? The cattle pasturing there on have been
removed because many died from eating
the ash covered grass. My naturalist says that
this mountain - as does Tursaba - gave out arsenic
in its fumes & ash, some 60 years ago! See what
one learnes by talking.

There is a very - or rather quite - pretty girl aboard
about 17 I judge & chaperoned by her father - do
you remember Eliza Espinoza's preference for a
father in that role - “one's mother knows so many
thing, one should not do” - & three students - re-
turning from the U.S., She is having the time
of her life, I hope she gets off at Guayaquil lest
it break up 3 promising romances, she is however
prettier than anyone I ever saw in Guayaquil
so may be she is from Lima.

OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE

TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE

I am well but had to put on extra un-
der clothes yesterday. I took them off this
morning - because it sh'd be worn in Guaya-
quil. & I am purposing with going ashore-
- as I have an Immune Certificate. Will put
them on again tomorrow & am glad of the
chance as my truck trunk is too full-
I told you so.

I get on very well with my spanish testa-
ment, possibly pay more attention than
if it were English.

I mail this in Guayaquill - so as to both
save time & avoid the Payta Postmistress
Love to all of you- This is my 5th letter - one of
them a note only. 2 from Havana: 2 from the Tivoli
& this one.
